ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Skills: How to structure a history research paper in history, how to engage with existing literature on a topic
Knowledge: I felt like I particularly learned a lot from the classes/readings/films on Black hair and fatness/obesity
if you want to know more about the little things that we never thought you would think about then take it!
Overview of history of the body

This course taught me about the historical and cultural significance of hair, facial cosmetic surgery, teeth, pregnancy, miscarriage, alcohol, fatness, the food industry, constipation, stool, cleanliness, germs, body odor, epidemics, and abortion. It also taught me how to analyze primary and secondary sources and how to be a better writer.
I learned how to critically evaluate primary sources, engage with secondary sources, and thoughtfully conduct discussions about the body and societal norms.
I learned extensively about the history of the body, including how to write a historical review and analysis.

I learned a lot about different parts of the body, the history of them, and how different cultures and people interact with them. Topics included hair, reproduction, hygiene, and death. We developed skills in the analysis of primary historical sources along with secondary sources. We then wrote essays on this analysis while also making claims about the present day. Another component of the course was the book club. We formed small groups and deeply analyzed and presented a secondary source on the history of the body.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed the class on body intakes, but I thought the class on body outtakes could be removed from the curriculum, and more time could be spent on infectious and dead bodies.
the teacher was really invested in the content and really wanted to hear the students thoughts
Very great prof

Strengths: The readings are very interesting and the discussions in class are very engaging. The class provides a very safe space to discuss the history of the body. Prof. Eisenberg is very knowledgeable, did a great job curating the course, is very approachable, and truly wants his students to learn and succeed. The midterm and final papers teach you how to analyze primary sources and write effectively. Weaknesses: None!

Strengths: This course was fantastic! The material was fascinating and Professor Eisenberg did a great job leading the discussion to allow for productive conversation.

No weaknesses.

I really enjoyed how the class was organized. The timeline in which we covered content was beneficial. I like how the discussions played out in class, and homework was quite reasonable outside of class.

strengths: we get thorough feedback on writing assignments which means that many writing assignments are not necessary, not a lot of busy work, discussions are fairly guided and we aren't expected to make new and substantial claims but just expected to share ideas, more relaxed seminar, book club was a good way to get exposed to more writing

weaknesses: we are given many readings but don't fully discuss them to the depth that they are written in, some classes were facilitated too much with little opportunity for us students to really bounce off of each other, sometimes too much new material (such as videos and clips) introduced in class so there is less time for discussion of the readings,

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes i would, i really liked the teacher and the ideas that we talked about in the course

YES! This is my favorite class I have taken at Yale. You get to discuss so many interesting topics that you cannot find in any other class. It will definitely make you see the body and the world differently. The class was a really great balance of learning from the professor and discussions.
Yes, love the prof.

Yes! HSHM 467 was definitely one of my favorite courses at Yale. The readings and lectures are all very interesting and Prof. Eisenberg is great! The people in the class provide a very welcoming and open space to discuss the course topics, and the different perspectives that we discuss have made it so that I will never the human body the same ever again (in a good way).
I would highly recommend this course to all students. The material is relevant to all of our lives, and the course allowed me to view the body differently.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially HSHM majors. It was very fascinating and engaging.

Yes, because I think the topics were very interesting. Although I wish we could've more thoroughly and productively discussed some things, it was fascinating to do the readings and hear classmates' perspectives. This course does require in-class participation but otherwise, it is not extremely challenging.
